content.title: Extremity Compartment Syndrome
content.summary: A surgical emergency characterized by elevated pressure within a closed fascial space compromising tissue perfusion, leading to muscle necrosis and permanent disability if not promptly treated with fasciotomy.

definitions.definition: Condition where increased pressure within a closed osteo-fascial compartment compromises the circulation and viability of tissues within that space.
The difference between diastolic blood pressure and measured compartment pressure. A delta pressure <30 mmHg is concerning and <20 mmHg is considered diagnostic.

key_concepts.explanation: The lower leg has four compartments: anterior (most commonly affected, contains deep peroneal nerve and anterior tibial vessels), lateral (superficial peroneal nerve), superficial posterior (gastrocnemius, soleus), and deep posterior (tibial nerve, posterior tibial vessels).

Pain (especially with passive stretch), Pressure (tense compartment), Paresthesias, Pallor, Pulselessness, and Paralysis. Pain out of proportion and pain with passive stretch are early and most sensitive findings. Loss of pulses is a late finding.

Four-compartment fasciotomy of the lower leg requires two incisions: lateral (anterior and lateral compartments) and medial (superficial and deep posterior). All four compartments must be released. Skin incisions are left open for delayed closure.
Reperfusion after prolonged ischemia (>4-6 hours) is a major cause of compartment syndrome. Prophylactic fasciotomy should be considered with revascularization after prolonged ischemia.

evidence.citation: McQueen et al., Compartment Pressure Monitoring Study, 2000
evidence.finding: Delta pressure <30 mmHg correlates with clinical compartment syndrome requiring fasciotomy

evidence.citation: Mubarak et al., Clinical Diagnosis Series, 1979
evidence.finding: Pain with passive stretch of muscles within the compartment is the most sensitive early clinical finding

clinical_pearls: Pulses are often present even in established compartment syndrome - do not wait for pulse loss
In obtunded patients, measure compartment pressures directly using a handheld pressure monitor
Delayed fasciotomy (>6-8 hours) results in significantly higher rates of amputation and mortality
Thigh compartment syndrome is less common but often missed - high index of suspicion with femur fractures
Forearm compartment syndrome requires volar and dorsal fasciotomy; carpal tunnel release may be needed
learning_objectives: Name the four compartments of the lower leg and their contents
Recognize early clinical signs of compartment syndrome
Calculate and interpret delta pressure for compartment syndrome diagnosis
Describe the two-incision four-compartment fasciotomy technique
Identify risk factors for post-revascularization compartment syndrome
